bug.short_desc: Handling a jira site over SSL requires tweaking my runtime cert store (annoying)

long_desc.thetext:
I seem to have to import SSL keys into my Eclipse runtime cacerts file in order for java to allow a SSL socket connection to a SSL secured Jira server. I have this second hand as the recommended way of doing things, I have a better way Id like to suggest, having had to do this very thing in a plugin project.
This all works by pointing some environment variables to a manufactured keystore kept in the plugins state path: System.getProperties().setProperty("javax.net.ssl.trustStore", af.getAbsolutePath()); //must be a resolvable FILE System.getProperties().setProperty("javax.net.ssl.trustStorePassword", "changeit");
First you need to get the cert from the server, then you need to import it into a keystore and use it. Ignoring how you get the cert in the first place, the attachment shows some cut and pasted methods that put the cert into a keystore in the plugines state location, update an environment variable and bobs your uncle without any JRE cacert tweaks.
I glossed over the question of how to extract the cert, I havent had to do this for my need and havent thought about it a great deal. I guess you could use 'openssl s_client -connect theserver:443' and chop the cert out of the stream, but obv, this is native 'linux' and not java. Maybe someone can figure this out...
comments?

Created an attachment (id=46019) Provides example of creating a TRUST cert store in a plugins state folder from a plugins resource.
The tricky bit is extracting a SSL Cert from a web server, IE has a neat way of doing this, shame firefox doesnt. I havent thought how this can be done programatically.
Looks like a duplicate of bug 147888. Also note that System.setProperty() generally is really bad idea when running from shared/controlled runtime where it can easily interfere with other plugins.

Andy, while waiting on bug 147888 please consider adding some tips on getting this going to:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_Contributor_Reference#JIRA
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 147888 ***

attachment.desc: Provides example of creating a TRUST cert store in a plugins state folder from a plugins resource.

bug.short_desc: NPE from FileModificationApprover

long_desc.thetext:
My GMF-based editor is opened on a file in plugin metadata area instead of workspace. This is done by puropse because the generated diagram file will be discarded by users in most of time and I don't want to pollute the workspace.
When changing the line style from Appearance tab, A NPE was thrown from FileModificationApprover.approveFileModification() inside for loop because nextFile is NULL:
for (Iterator i = fileModifier.getAffectedFiles().iterator(); i .hasNext();) { IFile nextFile = (IFile) i.next();
if (nextFile.exists()) {...}
After a bit of investigation, I noticed the affectedFiles associated in the compound command generated for "set routing" from ConnectionAppearancePropertySection had non-empty affect files but the actual element was null.
The reason is that the file in my editor is not in workspace. Also the command has an empty affect files list, the compound command still put this list as an element of its own affected file list.
This bug will affect all GMF-based editor which uses non workspace file as diagram resource.
I think it can be fixed by several ways: 1. The simple fix will be adding a null checking in FileModificationApprover.approveFileModification()
2. Or fixing it in CompoundCommand.getAffectedFiles by checking each command child's affected file list. If it was empty list, then do not add it to affected file list.
3. Or fixing in AbstractModelerPropertySection.createCommandInternal. It is the first place which introduced the problem. For file not in workspace, use a null as affected file instead of always returning a Collections.singletonList(WorkspaceSynchronizer.getFile(res). This is local fix but the similar problem may show up in other place.

Created an attachment (id=46024) patch for FileModificationApprover
Simple fix by adding a null checking in FileModificationApprover

Yes, the appearance tab works after this single change.
I will appreciate it very much if the fix can get into Eclipse 3.2.1. Otherwise, I have to put cumbersome workaround in my editor : I have to subclass AbstractModelerPropertySection and override createCommandInternal, also have to return my own tabbed property cotributor ID, specify all GMF properties tabs in my plugin so that my updated section can be used.
Made the requested fix in FileModificationApprover.
Fixed.

bug.short_desc: Should be able to use dynamic EMF instead of the generated code to store underlying diagram model

long_desc.thetext:
Currently generated diargamming code works only with the model code generated by EMF. Would be nice to have a possibility to generate code working with dynamic EMF feature. Use case: 1. Create .ecore domain meta-model (code was not generated for this .ecore model) 2. Create .gmfmap model 3. Transform .gmfmap-> .gmfgen 4. Generate code
Generated code should be able to load specified .ecore meta-model, create new instance of corresponding model using dynamic EMF/load it from the specified model file, create new diagram feasible to visualise this model.
I think, there should be an option in .gmfgen model "Use dynamic EMF" and different code should be generated in these two different situations.

"Dynamic EMF" is the term EMF's Developer Guide book uses to refer to the provided implementation of reflective API. Though 'Dynamic' is often percieved as something that is being contantly modified. Not sure 'dynamic' is most exact term here, as the use-case is about the frozen meta-model, one that can't be changed in run-time. Perhaps, 'codeless model' term would better describe the intention - don't generate the code, use EMF's reflective API to access meta-model.
Updated target milestone
Since GMF 2.0 M6 was released April 5, 2007, doing a bulk move of all open Bugzillas currently on M6 to 2.0 M7. Owners will need to access if the issue really is targetted for 2.0 M7.
Bulk update, descoping from 2.0

bug.short_desc: [Intro] [Intro] Detached stand-by intro part is in not in stand-by when reopened

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse version: 3.2 PC platform: Linux GTK
To reproduce in Eclipse IDE: 1.) Go to Help->Welcome, you get the full-screen mode Welcome. 2.) Deattach the welcome intro part outside of the main window. It switches to stand-by. 3.) Close the deattached intro with the Window (X) close button. It closes. 4.) Go to Help->Welcome again.
At this point, the deattached intro opens again, but it thinks it is NOT in standby mode, but draws the full mode UI in the narrowly sized deattached window, where before close/reopen it thought it was in standby mode.
This is not Universal Intro bug, but a plain Intro bug. I see it also in our RCP application, which uses intro screen, but DOES NOT USE Universal Intro framework.
I think this is in Platform UI.

bug.short_desc: [Actions] Make it possible to access an IAction prior to run(...) or selectionChanged(...)

long_desc.thetext:
It would be nice to have a possibility to access an IAction within an IViewActionDelegate already when the GUI creates it. Right now, one can only get it, when the methods run(...) or selectionChanged(...) of IViewActionDelegate are triggered.
I'd recommend to create an interface IViewActionDelegate2 subclassing IViewActionDelegate and providing an init(IViewPart, IAction) method or something like that.
The same applies to IWorkbenchActionDelegate.
Why do we need this?
Besides the selection, there are many events that require to programatically modify the Action (e.g. setEnabled(...)). For example, when using the RCP in a client-server-environment, an object might be modified on the server affecting the action's status or requiring the icon to be changed on the client side.
Yours sincerely,
Tobias Langner
I understand the rationale, but I wonder if that would be worth doing things on actions as they winding down being replaced by commands. May be commands can already help there?

There are currently no plans to work on this feature.
PW
Changes requested on bug 193523

This item has been fixed/superceded by the menu contribution mechanism - bug 154130
For commands, enablement is controlled by the handler and other properties for UI elements like label or icon can be refreshed by a request to ICommandService.
PW

bug.short_desc: Mildly annoying API omission in ModuleFactoryDelegate

long_desc.thetext:
There is no way for a ModuleFactoryDelegate to get a reference to it's enclosing ModuleFactory. This may indeed be by design, however it is a bit annoying.
If it's important that ModuleFactoryDelegate.factory remain private (and not protected), I suggest ModuleFactoryDelegate provide a protected getFactory(). Admittedly ModuleFactory doesn't contain a lot of functionality, however it keeps a cache of the modules. My implementing module factory delegate occasionally needs to clear this cache through the public method ModuleFactory.clearModuleCache().
For now I'm forced to do the following: ServerPlugin.findModuleFactory(FACTORY_ID).clearModuleCache();
This isn't too horrible but I simply don't think my factory should have to keep it's ID in order to get a reference to it's wrapper. Feel free to shoot me down though.

Created an attachment (id=46540) Possible patch for 150181 and 140916
Hi Rob, I agree this should be exposed, and I realized that your request for bug 140916 did not involve exposing ModuleFactory (which would be a big deal since it's internal). I've also checked and I can make extremely safe API additions for 1.5.1 where required. Can you please take a look at the changes in this patch and see if it solves both of these bugs for you?
The patch is beautiful. Just what the doctor ordered =]
Changes dropped to HEAD. I've missed this week's I-build cutoff but will release shortly.
*** Bug 140916 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Released for the next WTP 1.5.1 & 2.0 builds.
Closing.
This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.LocationManager builds an invalid URL in public static void initializeLocations()

long_desc.thetext: I believe that the MalformedURLException is being caught on line 86 and then on line 92 a file: URL is being created from the "c:/file" string. Are you seeing different behaviour?

Sorry for the delay in answering.
Yes, you're right, the exception is caught. I see how it method works now, though it seems a bit messy to use exceptions as part of the control flow.
This code is messy, but unfortunately it has lots of different scenarios to support and we need to be very careful making changes in this area.

The code is working as designed. The method needs to support taking a random URL and a file path. We support randon URLs by creating a new URL out of it. If this fails then we assume the spec is not a valid URL and we try to create a File out of it.

bug.short_desc: add submission of interaction history with bug reports

long_desc.thetext: One challenge with resolving bugs is figuring out what user actions triggered them. The Mylar Monitor component (used for previous user studies and not currently distributed) can provide this information since it logs almost all user interactions with Eclipse. This enables adding an additional page to the New Repository Task wizard which will allow the user to submit the last n events from their interaction, and obfuscate them for the privacy of the elements they worked on if desired. This notion of context is orthogonal to task contexts and would not depend on a task having been active.

bug.short_desc: Copy Errors at Runtime to Server Output Logs

long_desc.thetext:
We had a problem crop up today where we were we were running a report on a test server where the database was missing a needed column of data. The report was being generated as a PDF via the Web Report Viewer. Unfortunately, the only error dumped to the Tomcat server log had nothing to do with the missing data column. It wasn't until we ran the report as HTML output that we saw what the error was.
To aid in debugging and quick resolution, it would be a great help if you could extend the error handling for the PDF emitter to output these errors (similar to what the HTML emitter produces in such situations) to the server log.

User can customize the log by configuration. By default, birt turns off the log. User can turn on birt log by changing web.xml in plugins/org.eclipse.birt.report.viewer/birt/WEB-INF.
You can find the line: <!-- Report engine log level --> context-param> <param-name>BIRT_VIEWER_LOG_LEVEL</param-name> <param-value>OFF</param-value> </context-param>
change OFF to WARNING, then you can get the log in folder plugins/org.eclipse.birt.report.viewer/birt/logs .
The engine has output the log out if the user uses correct config.

bug.short_desc: merge Task List back/forward buttons into single history drop-down

long_desc.thetext: We should consider merging the buttons to be similar to JUnit's since the forward may not justify the space it takes up.

Rob, since we're all pretty clear this is the way to go I think you hsould do this asap. This is partly motivated by the fact that I'm takking screenshots for the Developer Works article. Just use one of the current icons for now, I'll fix them later.
You should consider adding timestamps to the entries like JUnit has, but they might clutter the labels too much since we need space for the descriptions.
In terms of implementation, you should probably be able to merge the forward and back stacks into one. I'm guessing that the most obvious thing that going back to a task does is bring it to the top of the stack, and the stack is simply sorted by time.

Last updated timestamps is really good idea, but please put it on front of the task description and use more compact and internationalized version of the timestamp comparing to what JUnit is using.
BTW, it would be nice to bring "Collapse All" acton right on the toolbar...

Created an attachment (id=46486) mylar/context/zip
Committed: Hybrid solution based on back button and JUnit menu design. Time stamps not implemented (should probably come from the task activity history facility).

> Committed: Hybrid solution based on back button and JUnit menu design. Time > stamps not implemented (should probably come from the task activity history > facility).
Hmm. Active or most recent task should be always on top, but it doesn't.

Currently, if you activate tasks from the tasklist they go on top (chronologically populate the history). If you select the back button or a previous task via the history drop down, that task is checked and becomes active (but as you noted it stays where it was chronologically). This can be useful for when you want look at/activate the tasks as they happened. Of course if nobody likes this we can just always float it to the top and get rid of the positional check mark. :)

There is a problem that when a task is activated using the context menu in the bug editor the task isn't getting added to the history. This may have been why the back/forward buttons were occasionally inconsistent. I'll resolve as part of this report.

Looked into this further and in fact that is what is happening, the contributed activate action doesn't add to task activation history (and never has). This motivates the need to do further extraction of the activation history from the ui and into the task list manager.

Update: - Activation from editors now recorded in activation history - Pressing back button steps back in history as it occurred (check mark indicates where) - Picking from history drop down brings selected task to top of history stack - Activation from editor and task list places on top of history stack
Marking Fixed.

bug.short_desc: Allow Java code for Scripted Data Set to access parameters

long_desc.thetext: Currently a Scripted Data Set which is implemented by Java event handlers does not have access to the inputParams and outputParams objects necessary to access in/out parameter values (see related Bug 132432 - that implementation has enabled parameter access in Javascript code). Please enhance Report Engine scripting API to allow Java-based scripted data sets to use input/output parameters.

Please see http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.birt/msg17166.html and http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.birt/msg17171.html where the bug is described.
As it says the parameter with correct value is "visible" in the debugger but the get-method to this part of the object is not public (inParamValues part of IDataSetInstance parameter in the fetch-method).
I believe the fix for this should be quit easy ...?
any idea when it's gonna happen? to elegantly implement pojo scripted data sets this feature is crucial - and it's peanuts implementing it!!!

This feature is also very important for our project. We want to implement a generic ScriptedDataSetEventAdapter for POJOs and need this feature for implementing master detail relations.
It should be so easy to add public getters for the inputParams and outputParams.

bug.short_desc: second frame selected instead of top frame after step return

long_desc.thetext:
3.2 and 3.3
This problem happens intermittently:
* Turn on "Show Monitors" * Step into a synchronized method (monitor appears above top frame) * Step out, releasing the lock > sometimes the second from top frame is selected rather than the top frame

Marking as 3.2.1 candidate.
The problem is in "preservingSelection", which can be called in a non-UI thread. When called in a non-UI thread, a cache of the current selection is made and restored later asynchronously. Between the time of calling "preserve selection" and restoring the selection, the selection could be set again, such that preserving the selection wipes out the selection that was set.

Created an attachment (id=46259) Patch
Released to HEAD and 3.2.1 branch
Fixed.
Please verify, Mike.
verified.
*** Bug 149904 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Determine project facet support before creating runtime

long_desc.thetext:
Maybe I've missing something, but I don't understand how a component would go about determining whether a given server would support a project's facets before creating the server's runtime. For instance, a Web Service wizard might want to determine if Tomcat supports a given project before it creates a Tomcat server to run the contents of the project. The only way that I can currently see how to do this is to create the runtime and call IRuntime.supports(), but we need a way to do this before the runtime exists.
Please let me know if API exists (and what it is) or how this should be done. The implementation that I'll need to fix given the result of this bug is FacetUtil.verifyFacets() in jst.server.

That's right, there is currently no way to do the "supports" check without having an instance of IRuntime. While I can certainly add such api as part of the re-work of the runtime api for 2.0, the use cases such as this should really be re-examined. Why? Facet support is determined by exactly which runtime components and versions end up in the runtime. The problem is that you cannot know this before the runtime is created. Right now, based on which runtime wizard is selected, you know the server runtime type and version, but you do not know the java runtime version. That is only determined when the user selects a java runtime inside the wizard. In 2.0 this becomes even more pronouced as runtimes will be able to have any number of runtime components and we need to support the use case of users creating runtime of any version from a single wizard (for example, launch "New WebLogic Runtime" wizard, point at install location, we figure out the rest). With the wizard in full control over what set of runtime components and versions will compose the created runtime, there will be very little you can assume before hand and we will need to revisit the UI that currently relies on being able to make such assumptions.
*** Bug 161815 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Tim,
I am sending this back your way for a comment rather than just closing. See my Comment #1. What I am thinking is that the direction that we are heading in means that the question of "which runtime creation wizard creates a runtime of type x" will not be something that we will be able to answer. We can discuss this more offline, if you'd like.

FWIW, with the current server tools API you can create a runtime and call the API to check - as long as you don't call save() the runtime never existed. Konstantin's right that this doesn't work in cases where the user might pick the JRE version, etc. At best we could provide a best-guess API or one that would check the minimal runtime components.
At some point we should probably check with the web services team, since they have some 'complex' cases where they try to do project-server mapping in their wizards before either are created... they expect this info to be available beforehand and then simply create everything when the user hits Finish. As you might expect this doesn't entirely work today :), but it actually comes pretty close.

Duping this against the Common Runtime Modeling Component task. Any new api to support this (such as ability to create a runtime without saving it) will have to come as the result of that work.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 159169 ***
Closing as part of mass query to clean up old resolved bugs in untargetted milestones.

bug.short_desc: [misc] Java editor is not updated if the file is deleted and recreated again in less than 1 seconds

long_desc.thetext: The code is using java.io.File and not IFile i.e. changes the local file system. The editor gets these changes only if workspace auto-refresh is enabled (which seems to be the case in your scenario) and the refresh happens on an fixed interval which is causing what you see.

Auto-refresh is activated.
1.scenario The code uses IFile.delete() method to delete the file(1. step) Then a file with the same name is written by FileOutputStream (2.step)
Time time intreval between the step 1 and 2 is really small(much smaller than 1 sec)
In this scenario, it seems like when IFile.delete is called, it invokes a method to close that file on text editor if there is any. And I also assume that IFile.delete() removes time stamps of deleted file which is a correct behavior. Then when a file is created by using File instead of IFile with the same name, the invoked method to close the file on the text editor is confused since the file with that name exists. And I think, since tehre is no time stamps of preciously deleted file, it can not compare, so it leaves the old file as it is.
2.scenario :
// Commented; The code uses IFile.delete() method to delete the file(1. step) Then a file with the same name is written by FileOutputStream (2.step)
But if you remove the step 1 (IFile.delete()) from the code, the text editor is updated automatically and it does not ask the user to load changes. On the other side, if you change the file from file system, it asks you that "file is changed, would you like to load the changes?".
3. scenario
The code uses IFile.delete() method to delete the file(1. step) Wait 2-3 seconds A file with the same name is written by FileOutputStream (2.step)
If you wait 2-3 seconds after you delete file with IFile.delete method, it gives enough time to eclipse editor to close the file if it is open on text editor.
I think the problem that when file is deleted, it invokes a method to close it on text editor, and that method check whether file is really deleted, and if the file exists, that method should call a method to load that file again to text editor instead of doing nothing.
I think you can try the following code after some modifications on your workspace,
IFile sampleIFile = ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot().getFileForLocation(new Path(samplePath)); IProject project = IFile.getProject(); sampleIFile.delete(true, new NullProgressMonitor()); //step 1 described above File file = new File(samplePath); FileOutputStream fout = new FileOutputStream(file); //step2 described above file.write("bla bla"); project.refreshLocal(IResource.DEPTH_INFINITE, new NullProgressMonitor());
We rely on the resource delta being sent from Core.
- could you attach a little plug-in that demonstrates this? - what happens if you disable the auto-refresh of the workspace?

Created an attachment (id=46373) Sample plugin to reproduce failure
Steps to reproduce with this sample plugin:
1) Create a general project "p1" 2) Create file "a.txt" within this project 3) When the editor on a.txt opens, type some text to dirty the editor 4) Click the "Hello World" button on the toolbar
The sample action calls IFile.delete, followed by creating a new file at the same location using java.io.FileOutputStream. Using the core tools plugin I see the resource delta is reported correctly: deletion of a.txt followed by creation of a.txt. However, the editor is not affected, and when I save the dirty editor it does not warn me that I am overwriting new contents in the local file system. If the editor is not dirty when the action is run, the editor behaves correctly.

Note that I could not reproduce the bug with the exact supplied sample code, because it did not close the output stream - this results in strange behaviour on Windows (the file may or may not exist, and cannot be deleted).
Strange. Needs to be investigated.

OK, I see now what's happening: we currently have no means to tell the user that the file has been deleted: either we immediately act upon the deletion (discards the changes made in the Eclipse editor) or we ignore it (current behavior. We always ignore changes when the editor is dirty).

bug.short_desc: ConfigurationAdmin seems to deadlock during ManagedService registration

long_desc.thetext:
I have been kicking the tires of the Configuration Admin implementation in the incubator and I believe that I've found a case where registering a ManagedService results in a dead-lock, probably caused by Configuration Admin.
I cannot prove anything yet, since running under the control of the Eclipse debugger results in the problem not happening. Frankly, while this is frustrating, it does support my believe that there's a dead-lock somewhere.
I'll do some more investigations and then attach my test case.

Created an attachment (id=46048) Zip containing two Eclipse plug-in projects.
Extract the zip into an existing workspace and import the projects using File > Import > Existing Projects into Workspace.
Simply launch the test case bundles, plus Configuration Admin and the necessary prerequisites. It is recommended that you set the Start Level of the Configuration Admin bundle to 1 since my test case bundle that acquires the service does not bother tracking or listening for it.
When the timing is "just right" you should see the following messages coming out of the counter bundle's activator:
*** About to Register ManagedService *** ... *** Registered Managed Service ***
When the deadlock happens you don't see the second message.

As a sanity check, I commented-out all the synchronized blocks in my code, since it occurred to me that maybe the problem was in the test case's handing of the ManagedService updated(Dictionary) call back from Configuration Admin. Suffice to say, the problem still exists, so I'm more confident that the problem is with the Configuration Admin bundle. Additionally, I have run an earlier version of the test case on another implementation of Configuration Admin without problem.
The best news is that I managed to get the problem to happen under the control of the Eclipse debugger. I shall attached a text file containing the stacks.
Created an attachment (id=46055) Thread stacks
Thanks for the great test case -- very easy to reproduce. I think the ManagedServiceTracker and ManagedServiceFactoryTracker are a little to broad in their synchronization. Patch on the way...

Thanks Simon... Glad the test case worked well for you. As it turns out, I wrote the code as an example to explain how to use ConfigurationAdmin and ManagedServices to others, so it just kinda worked out as a good test case too.
As I mentioned before, I also have a proprietary implementation of ConfigurationAdmin here, so it made this rather easy to test. The implementation I have has been around for years and years, so I have some confidence in it.
Once you attach the patch I shall apply it and retest.

Created an attachment (id=46120) more fine grained synchronization patch
Here's a patch that no longer deadlocks (at least in my testing) -- I'm still doing some thinking and further verification work here but the general approach is to synchronize the trackers in a more fine grained manner.
Also, I think this implementation will need to be re-verified with TCK when the patch is final.

When I applied the patch Eclipse complained as follows:
The method getService is defined in an inherited type and an enclosing scope.
This was for line 232 of the class ConfigurationAdminFactory. Maybe it's a compiler setting that you have relaxed, but I'm pretty sure my compiler settings are set to the defaults. The work around, of course was to identify the getService method more precisely by prefixing it with "this.". Note that it is only the name of the method that is ambiguous -- when you consider the method signature it is not ambiguous, so I find this error to be a little strange. But I'm not a Java compiler expert, so perhaps method names really must be unique when working with inner-classes.
Once I got the patch to compile, it worked great. Once the patch has been cleaned up, and the TCK has been passed, I would consider this bug RESOLVED/FIXED.
Thanks Simon for providing the patch so promptly.

Created an attachment (id=46149) more fine grained synchronization patch
Updated the patch to use "this" when referencing getService. No idea where the ambiguity comes from. I also thought I was using the default compiler settings ;) [using Sun JDK 1.5.0_07, 3.2 release, 1.4 compliance with default compliance settings, and default compiler error and warning settings] [I'm guessing the issue may be with the Eclipse compiler as opposed to the JRE ??]
Any way... "this" works for me at least for the time being.

Created an attachment (id=46176) more fine grained synchronization patch
Mainly cleanup of the previous patch. The previous patch was a little over-zealous in not tracking services when encountering problems in configuration objects.
I'll keep testing with this but will likely update the depot with it later on today. Once we've confirmed the TCK still passes I'll come back and mark fixed.
The latest code Simon released in HEAD does pass the OSGi TCK. Simon is this bug now fixed?

In reply to comment #10) > The latest code Simon released in HEAD does pass the OSGi TCK. Simon is this > bug now fixed? Thanks Tom. I think the immediate problem is gone however I still want to review a little more next week before marking fixed.

I am also interested in testing the use of the ManagedServiceFactory side of ConfigurationAdmin. Of course any problem related to the use of a ManagedServiceFactory probably deserves its own bug report, so don't wait for me to change this one to RESOLVED/FIXED. I'm happy with Simon's patch.

The first patch prevents the deadlock however after looking at this a bit more thoroughly I think there's a race condition in the two trackers between adding a service and delivering an asynch event. It's possible (although incredibly unlikely) that an update or delete event could be lost or possibly delivered out of order.
I can't really see this coming up in regular use however I'll start working on a patch.

Created an attachment (id=46481) lock based approach
In this patch the block level synchronization on configuration objects has been replaced with an equivalent mutex mechanism. I found there were a few of the standard list locking situations where block-level synchronization is really akward. Unfortunately this means that a lot of the code has been modified however it's a bit misleading as I really don't believe event ordering or the various callbacks should have been altered in a meaningful way.
...more testing required, but I've re-run your (SimonA's) testcase succesfully and have started more of my own. I'd appreciate it if you could try this patch out.

Created an attachment (id=46518) lock based approach (Final)
Same as last patch but cleans up a few things: 1. Adds config.checkLocked() calls when locking is assumed outside of ConfigImpl 2. move the configstore.save() calls inside the config.lock and removed the requirement for it to be synchronized. 3) moved the service return call in ManagedServiceTracker.adding to be inside the synchronized configstore block.
At this point I think the patch is final and I'll move it onto the HEAD in the incubator shortly. There's no real rush but at some point the TCK needs to be run again to make sure I haven't broken anything. (... and apologies as I'd do this myself if I could). After we've confirmed this bug can "finally" be marked FIXED.
This is fixed. Please re-open if there's still a problem. I don't have access to the TCK but certainly before considering graduating this we should re-run.
